[[Benjamin of Tiberias]] |strength1=Byzantine Empire *Christian rebels *[[Byzantine Army]] |strength2=Sasanian Empire *[[Military of the Sasanian Empire|Sassanian army]] *20,000 or 26,000 Jewish rebels{{cite book | title = A history of Palestine from 135 A.D. to modern times |author= James Parkes|publisher = Victor Gollancz| year = 1949| accessdate= 8 June 2014}}{{rp| 81}} |casualties1=Tens of thousands |casualties2=Tens of thousands }} {{Campaignbox Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628}} {{History of Israel}} The '''Jewish revolt against Heraclius''' was part of the [[Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628]] and is considered the last serious Jewish attempt for gaining autonomy in Palestine prior to modern times. According to a recent theory, the revolt and the general Byzantine-Persian War took place during the [[Late Antique Little Ice Age]], which marked the decline of the classic empires, demographic and economic collapse across the Near East and rise of opportunistic forces, such as Muslim Arabs and Turks. Following the [[Battle of Antioch (613)|Battle of Antioch]] in 613, [[Shahrbaraz]] led his forces through [[Palaestina Secunda]] and into [[Palaestina Prima]] provinces.{{rp| 123}} In 614, Shahrbaraz [[Siege of Caesarea (614)|conquered Caesarea Maritima]], the administrative capital of the Palaestina Prima province.{{rp| 206}} The Persian army reinforced by Jewish forces led by [[Nehemiah ben Hushiel]] and [[Benjamin of Tiberias]] would shortly capture Jerusalem without resistance.{{rp| 207}} After only a few months a Christian revolt occurred. Nehemiah ben Hushiel and his council of sixteen righteous were killed along with many other Jews, some throwing themselves off the city walls.{{rp| 69–71}}{{rp|169}} Christians were able to briefly retake the city before the walls were breached by Shahrbaraz’s forces who lay siege to the city.{{rp| 207}} According to the Armenian bishop and historian [[Sebeos]] the siege resulted in a total Christian death toll of 17,000,{{rp| 207}} Christian sources later exaggerated the extent of the massacre, claiming a death toll as high as 90,000.{{rp| 207–208}} In addition 35,000 or 37,000 people including the patriarch Zacharias are said to have been deported to Mesopotamia.{{rp| 69–71}}{{rp| 123}}{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_qmpcSlB8wYC&pg=PA15&dq=jerusalem+37000+614&hl=en&sa=X&ei=oEf2U6-jBYWTyQTMi4LIBQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=37000%20&f=false| title = Jews of Spain: A History of the Sephardic Experience| author= Jane S. Gerber|publisher = Simon and Schuster| page = 15| year = 1994|accessdate= 27 January 2015}} The city is said to have been burnt down. However, neither wide spread burning nor destruction of churches have been found in the archaeological record. Bands of Jews from Jerusalem, Tiberias, Galilee, Damascus, and even from Cyprus, united and undertook an incursion against Tyre, having been invited by the 4,000 Jewish inhabitants of that city to surprise and massacre the Christians on Easter night. The Jewish army is said to have consisted of 20,000 men. The expedition, however, miscarried, as the Christians of Tyre learned of the impending danger, and seized the 4,000 Tyrian Jews as hostages. The Jewish invaders destroyed the churches around Tyre, an act which the Christians avenged by killing two thousand of their Jewish prisoners. The besiegers, to save the remaining prisoners, withdrew. The Jews had hoped that [[Khosrau II]] would give them all of the [[Land of Israel]] in exchange for their support. By 617 CE the Persians had reversed their policy and sided with the Christians over the Jews, probably because of pressure from Mesopotamian Christians in Persia itself.{{rp| 208}}{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=z10-Xz9Kno4C&pg=PA347#v=onepage&q=614&f=false| title = A Psychoanalytic History of the Jews| year = 1996| pages =353–354| author = Avner Falk | accessdate = 2014-03-10 | publisher = Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press}} By 622 CE, the [[Byzantine Emperor]] [[Heraclius]] had assembled an army to retake the territory lost to the [[Sasanian Empire]]. In 628, following the deposition of [[Khosrau II]], [[Kavadh II]] made peace with Heraclius, but Kavadh II would only have a brief reign. It is said that Benjamin even accompanied Heraclius on his voyage to Jerusalem and Benjamin was persuaded to convert, Benjamin obtained a general pardon for himself and the Jews.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-xY1qsioqd8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Palestine+in+Late+Antiquity&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kYU1U6P6AvSksQT9l4GwDA&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=614&f=false | title = Palestine in Late Antiquity |authors= Hagith Sivan |publisher = Oxford University Press | page = 2: Anastasian Landscapes page 8| year = 2008| accessdate= 28 March 2014}} On 21 March 630, Emperor Heraclius marched in triumph into Jerusalem with the True Cross.{{cite book |title= The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars Ad 363-628, Part 2| editors = Michael H. Dodgeon, Samuel N. C. Lieu| publisher = Taylor & Francis | pages = 227–228|year = 2002|accessdate=12 March 2014}} A general massacre of the Jewish population ensued. The massacre devastated the Jewish communities of the [[Galilee]] and Jerusalem.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IR9rNAai2koC&pg=PA93&dq=Ghassanid+Galilee+jews+629&hl=en&sa=X&ei=N-UsU5K6B_LyyAG0noCYAQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Ghassanid%20Galilee%20jews%20629&f=false| title = Yarmuk AD 636: The Muslim Conquest of Syria|date = 1994| author = David Nicolle |publisher = Osprey Publishing| page=93 |accessdate=21 March 2014}}{{cite book |title=Catastrophe: An Investigation into the Origins of the Modern World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wpGN4ekwHgYC&pg=PT104&dq=Heraclius+massacre+Galilee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uMzJVLGcM8WbNvTTgdgI&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Heraclius%20massacre%20Galilee&f=false| author=David Keys |publisher=Random House Publishing Group |year=2000 |accessdate=28 January 2015}}{{cite book |title= Byzantium and the Early Islamic Conquests |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2bsLAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT129&dq=Heraclius+massacre+Galilee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uMzJVLGcM8WbNvTTgdgI&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Heraclius%20massacre%20Galilee&f=false |author=Walter E. Kaegi |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1992 |accessdate=28 January 2015}} Only those Jews who could flee to the mountains or Egypt are said to have been spared.{{rp| 38}} Some historians believe the war reduced and weakened the Christian population not just in Jerusalem but across the Near East, allowing the success of the following Arab invasion. However, over the past thirty years the archaeological evidence has not supported the ancient manuscripts which record the devastation of the Christian community in Jerusalem.{{cite web | url = https://www.academia.edu/3808482/_Archaeology_Versus_Written_Sources_the_Case_of_the_Persian_Conquest_of_Jerusalem_in_614_| title = Archaeology Versus Written Sources: the Case of the Persian Conquest of Jerusalem in 614 | publisher = Terra antique balcanica et mediterranea, Miscellanea in Honour of Alexandet Minchev, Acta Museii Varnaensis, VIII-1, 2011 |date= January 2011 |website= academia.edu | accessdate =27 January 2015| authors = Yuri Stoyanov }}{{rp| 353}} ==Background== Jews and Samaritans were persecuted frequently by the Byzantines (eastern Romans) resulting in numerous [[Samaritan Revolts|revolts]]. Byzantine religious propaganda developed strong [[Anti-Judaism|anti-Jewish]] elements.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JRibSFLMER8C&printsec=copyright#v=onepage&q=90000&f=false | title = The Armenian History Attributed to Sebeos |authors= R. W. THOMSON Historical commentary by JAMES HOWARD-JOHNSTON Assistance from TIM GREENWOOD. |publisher = Liverpool University Press| year = 1999 | accessdate= 17 January 2014}}{{rp| lxiii, 195}}{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4DNz3y7Wep4C&pg=PA790&lpg=PA790&dq=circus+jerusalem+614&source=bl&ots=hkENRaiego&sig=kJZ7ISRP7rRDRld3JMp2EKE1-K0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xsDZUqvOHMO0sASDuICgBA&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=jerusalem%20614&f=false| title = Jews in Byzantium: Dialectics of Minority and Majority Cultures|editors= Robert Bonfil, Oded Ishai, Guy G. Stroumsa, Rina Talgam|publisher = Hotei Publishing the Netherlands | year = 2012 | accessdate= 17 January 2014}}{{rp| 81–83, 790–791}}{{cite book |title= East Rome, Sasanian Persia and the End of Antiquity: Historiographical and Historical Studies |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1U4rUaLdYnQC&pg=RA1-PA158&lpg=RA1-PA158&dq=Sasanian+Echoes+and+Apocalyptic+Expectations&source=bl&ots=TtTUNMzHda&sig=cmT2g1FtZyNe0LeDYKbO41FuXqo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_KMjU-O7B-KYyAGF5oCYCQ&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=614&f=false | author = J. D. Howard-Johnston |publisher = Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., |pages = 124–125, 142 |year = 2006|accessdate=14 March 2014}} In several cases Jews tried to help support the Sasanian advance. A pogrom in [[Antioch]] in 608 would lead to a Jewish revolt in 610 which was crushed. Jews also revolted in both [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] and [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] in 610. The Jews of Tyre were massacred in reprisal. Unlike in earlier times when Jews had supported Christians in the fight against [[Shapur I]], the Byzantines had now become viewed as oppressors.{{cite book |title= a history of the jews in babylonia v. later sasanian times |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zrM3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA122&dq=610+pogrom&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PH8fU7zbFMHLqQHvwoCIBg&ved=0CCgQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=610%20pogrom&f=false | author = Jacob Neusner |publisher = Brill Archive|year = 1970 |accessdate=11 March 2014}}{{rp| 122}} The territory is said to have had a substantial indigenous Jewish population at this time. [[James Parkes (clergyman)|James Parkes]] estimates that if ten percent of the Jewish population joined the revolt and the figure of 20,000 rebels is correct then 200,000 Jews were living in the territory at the time.{{rp| 65}} Likewise [[Michael Avi-Yonah]] used the figure of Jewish combatants to arrive at an estimate of the total Jewish population. He gives a figure of 150,000 to 200,000 living in 43 Jewish settlements. [[Salo Wittmayer Baron]] in 1957 questioned the reliability of the number of Jewish combatants recorded in ancient texts and the population estimates based on these texts, although he does not discount the estimate altogether. He reasons that the 43 Jewish settlements Avi-Yonah lists may indeed be supportive of a minority Jewish presence of 10 to 15%.{{cite book | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xrUh7xGY0wIC&pg=PA237&dq=jews+150,000+43+settlements++614&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAWoVChMIluuc59nKxgIVRlk-Ch1hjwFK#v=onepage&q=jews%20150%2C000%2043%20settlements%20%20614&f=false| title = Social and Religious History of the Jews, Volume 3: High Middle Ages: Heirs of Rome and Persia |authors= Salo Wittmayer Baron | publisher = Columbia University Press|pages = 237| year = 1957}} [[Jacob Neusner]] similarly accepts this estimate.{{rp| 124}} In 1950 Israel Cohen gave an estimate of double these values, estimating that between 300,000 and 400,000 Jews were in the land.Israel Cohen (1950). Contemporary Jewry: a survey of social, cultural, economic, and political conditions. Methuen. p. 310. More recently [[Moshe Gil]] has postulated that the combined Jewish and Samaritan population was a majority in the early 7th century.Moshe Gil, A History of Palestine: 634–1099, p. 3. Jews are thought to have been concentrated in the [[Galilee]] during this time period. The Galilee is said to have contained several cities which are thought to have been populated largely by a homogenous Jewish demographic, [[Tiberias]] being a center of Jewish learning. In fact the title of the [[Jerusalem Talmud]] is something of a misnomer as it was actually compiled in [[Tiberias]],{{cite book | url= https://archive.org/stream/biblicalresearch03robiuoft#page/269/mode/1up 269| title = Biblical researches in Palestine, Mount Sinai and Arabia Petraea a journal of travels in the year 1838 by E. Robinson and E. Smith, undertaken in reference to Biblical geography; drawn up from the original diaries, with historical illustrations by Edward Robinson. |authors= E. Robinson and E. Smith |publisher = Crocker in Boston |pages = 268–270 | year = 1841 | accessdate= 28 January 2015}} as Jews were banned from Jerusalem.{{cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Jerusalem/p/period3-2.htm|last=Zank|first=Michael|publisher=Boston University|title=Byzantian Jerusalem|accessdate= 15 March 2014}} ==Timeline== ===Galilee and Caesarea=== Following the [[Battle of Antioch (613)|Battle of Antioch]] in 613, [[Shahrbaraz]] led his forces through Palaestina Secunda and into Palaestina Prima provinces.{{rp| 123}} Shahrbaraz [[Siege of Caesarea (614)|conquered Caesarea Maritima]], the administrative capital of the Palaestina Prima province.{{rp| 206}} When Shahrbaraz had entered Galilee, a significant Jewish revolt took place with some 20,000 Jewish rebels joining him in the war against the Byzantines.{{rp| 123}}{{cite book |url = http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/4356-chosroes-khosru-ii-parwiz| title = Jewish Encyclopedia CHOSROES (KHOSRU) II. PARWIZ ("The Conqueror"):| authors= Th. Nöldeke, Grätz, Gesch|publisher = Jewish Encyclopedia| year = 1906 |accessdate= 20 January 2014}} Depending on the chronicler figures of either 20,000 or 26,000 are given.{{rp| 81}} The Sasanian Persians were joined by [[Nehemiah ben Hushiel]]{{cite book |title= A History of the Jewish People |url =https://books.google.com/books?id=2kSovzudhFUC&pg=PA362&lpg=PA362&dq=nehemiah+ben+hushiel&source=bl&ots=0cBuk-7EKf&sig=OSgCfQ9uV8Z86FhQ3y616Jfg4M&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AT7WUtLJGIOhkQeO2ICgBQ&sqi=2&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=nehemiah%20ben%20hushiel&f=false | author = Haim Hillel Ben-Sasson |publisher = Harvard University Press |page = 362 |year = 1976 |accessdate=19 January 2014}} and [[Benjamin of Tiberias]] (a man of immense wealth), who enlisted and armed Jewish soldiers from [[Tiberias]], [[Nazareth]] and the mountain cities of [[Galilee]], and together with a band of Arabs and additional Jews from southern parts of the country they marched on Jerusalem. ===Capture of Jerusalem=== {{main|Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem}} The Persian army reinforced by Jewish forces led by Nehemiah ben Hushiel and Benjamin of Tiberias would capture Jerusalem without resistance.{{rp| 207}} The capture of Jerusalem was interpreted by Jewish writers in a messianic context. Sacrifices may even have been renewed on the [[Temple Mount]].{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u8xsv4Pqk-EC&pg=PA169&dq=solving+the+qilliri+riddle+fleischer&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3AiIVNGjHoGfgwSylIOoCQ&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=solving%20the%20qilliri%20riddle%20fleischer&f=false | title = Judaica Minora: Geschichte und Literatur des rabbinischen Judentums| author= Günter Stemberger | publisher =Mohr Siebeck| year = 2010| accessdate = 17 December 2014}}{{rp|168–169}} Control of the city was handed to [[Nehemiah ben Hushiel]] and [[Benjamin of Tiberias]]. Nehemiah was then appointed the ruler of Jerusalem.{{cite book |title= Itineraria Phoenicia|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=SLSzNfdcqfoC&pg=PA542&dq=Opusculum+de+Persica+captivitate&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IzofU5aPGIfiqAGVoIHwBw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Opusculum%20de%20Persica%20captivitate&f=false| author = Edward Lipiński |publisher = Peeters Publishers |pages = 542–543 |year = 2004 |accessdate=11 March 2014}} He began making arrangements for the building of the [[Third Temple]], and sorting out genealogies to establish a new High Priesthood.{{cite web | url = http://clas-pages.uncc.edu/john-reeves/research-projects/trajectories-in-near-eastern-apocalyptic/sefer-zerubbabel/| title = Sefer Zerubbabel | accessdate = 2014-01-17 | publisher = Translated by John C. Reeves. University of North Carolina at Charlotte}} ===Christian rebellion=== After only a few months a Christian revolt occurred. Nehemiah ben Hushiel and his council of sixteen righteous were killed along with many other Jews, some throwing themselves off the city walls.{{rp| 69–71}}{{rp|169}} Following the outburst of violence in Jerusalem, the surviving Jews fled to [[Shahrbaraz]]’s encampment at [[Caesarea Maritima|Caesarea]]. Christians were able to briefly retake the city before the walls were breached by Shahrbaraz’s forces who lay siege to the city.{{rp| 207}} Sources vary on how long the siege lasted. Depending on the source it lasted 19, 20 or 21 days. According to the Armenian bishop and historian [[Sebeos]] the siege resulted in a total Christian death toll of 17,000,{{rp| 207}} 4,518 prisoners were massacred near [[Mamilla Pool|Mamilla reservoir]] per [[Antiochus of Palestine|Antiochus Strategos]].[http://www.bibleinterp.com/articles/pers357904.shtml The Persian Conquest of Jerusalem (614 CE) – an archeological assessment] by Gideon Avni, Director of the Excavations and Surveys Department of the Israel Antiquities Authority. [[James Howard-Johnston]] argues that the massacre occurred in the context of the returning Jews attempting to round up the ring leaders who had led the earlier pogrom.{{rp| 207–208}} Christian sources later exaggerated the extent of the massacre, claiming a death toll as high as 90,000.{{rp| 207–208}} In addition 35,000 or 37,000 people including the patriarch Zacharias are said to have been deported to Mesopotamia.{{rp| 69–71}}{{rp| 123}} The city is said to have been burnt down. However, neither wide spread burning nor destruction of churches have been found in the archaeological record. The search for the [[True Cross]] is said to have involved the torture of clergymen.{{rp| 207}} Once found, the True Cross was carried off to [[Ctesiphon]].{{cite book |title= International Dictionary of Historic Places: Middle East and Africa, Volume 4|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=R44VRnNCzAYC&pg=PA193&dq=Ctesiphon+true+cross&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KcMgU_TQFuLCyQGWvYDgBA&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Ctesiphon%20true%20cross&f=false| editors = Trudy Ring, Robert M. Salkin, Sharon La Boda| publisher = Taylor & Francis| page = 193|year = 1996|accessdate=12 March 2014}} Unlike Sebeos, Antiochus uses polemical language.{{rp| 206–207, 195}} Antiochus wrote that the Jews offered to help the Christian captives escape death if they "become Jews and deny Christ." They refused. In anger, the Jews then purchased Christians to kill them.{{cite journal |url=http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/antiochus_strategos_capture.htm|title=Antiochus Strategos' Account of the Sack of Jerusalem in A.D. 614 |authorlink=Frederick Cornwallis Conybeare |first=F. C. |last=Conybeare |journal=[[English Historical Review]] |volume=25 |year=1910 |pages=502–517 |doi=10.1093/ehr/xxv.xcix.502}}{{[http://ehr.oxfordjournals.org/content/XXV/XCIX.toc EHR July, 1910]}} A significant number of burial sites were allocated according to Antiochus. A mass burial grave at [[Mamilla]] cave was discovered in 1989 by Israeli [[archeologist]] [[Ronny Reich]] near the site, where Antiochus recorded the massacre took place. The human remains were in poor condition containing a minimum of 526 individuals.[http://www.antiquities.org.il/article_Item_eng.asp?sec_id=17&sub_subj_id=179 "Human Skeletal Remains from the Mamilla cave, Jerusalem"] by Yossi Nagar. ===Jewish expedition to Tyre=== According to [[Patriarch Eutychius of Alexandria|Eutychius]] (887-940), the Jews launched an expedition against Tyre.{{cite book | url= https://archive.org/stream/libraryofpalesti11paleuoft#page/n57/mode/1up | title = Eucherius about certain holy places: The library of the Palestine Pilgrims' Text Society.|authors= Eutychius |publisher = Committee of the Palestine Exploration Fund in London.| year = 1896 | accessdate= 28 January 2015}}{{rp| 39–40}} Bands of Jews from Jerusalem, Tiberias, Galilee, Damascus, and even from Cyprus, united and undertook an incursion against Tyre, having been invited by the 4,000 Jewish inhabitants of that city to surprise and massacre the Christians on Easter night. The Jewish army is said to have consisted of 20,000 men. The expedition, however, miscarried, as the Christians of Tyre learned of the impending danger, and seized the 4,000 Tyrian Jews as hostages. The Jewish invaders destroyed the churches around Tyre, an act which the Christians avenged by killing two thousand of their Jewish prisoners. The besiegers, to save the remaining prisoners, withdrew, having had to suffer the humiliation of watching the heads of the Jewish captives as they were thrown over the walls.{{cite book |title= History of the Byzantine Jews: A Microcosmos in the Thousand Year Empire |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=r-9qJRP20MIC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false| author = Elli Kohen | publisher = University Press of America |year = 2007|accessdate=28 January 2015}}{{rp| 37}} ===Jewish control of Jerusalem=== The Jews had hoped that [[Khosrau II]] would give them all of the [[Land of Israel]] in exchange for their support. However they were too few to make this a reality.{{rp| 124}} For a time they are said to have enjoyed relative dominance in Jerusalem, although it may have been in a state of anarchy.{{rp| 208–209}} By 617 CE the Persians had reversed their policy and sided with the Christians over the Jews, probably because of pressure from Mesopotamian Christians in Persia itself.{{rp| 208}} Further Jewish settlers were banned from settling in or around Jerusalem and a small synagogue on the Temple Mount was also demolished.{{rp| 209–210}} Instead of supporting the Jews, Khosrau is said to have imposed heavy taxes on them.{{rp| 37}} ===Byzantine return to Jerusalem=== By 622 CE, the Roman Emperor Heraclius had assembled an army to retake the territory lost to the [[Sasanian Empire]]. In 628, following the deposition of [[Khosrau II]], [[Kavadh II]] made peace with [[Heraclius]], but Kavadh II would only have a brief reign. The conquered city and the Cross would remain in Sasanian hands until they were returned by Shahrbaraz. On 21 March 630, Heraclius marched in triumph into Jerusalem with the True Cross. Ancient manuscripts date Heraclius' entry into Jerusalem as 21 March 629.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} Modern scholars increasingly doubt this date for a number of reasons. ====Dating Byzantine return==== Walter Emil Kaegi puts the death of Kavadh II in September 629.{{cite book |title= Heraclius, Emperor of Byzantium|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tlNlFZ_7UhoC&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=Heraclius+629&source=bl&ots=GwO1I28Bok&sig=QMzxlGMMTBdpNOBBljUZ7loSBuo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KqogU8rjKuTeyQHh64GwCQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Heraclius%20629&f=false| author = Walter Emil Kaegi|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2003|accessdate=12 March 2014}}{{rp|187 }} The Persian succession between 628 and 632 becomes confused and different historians give different succession timelines.{{rp| 117}} In the period following the death of Kavadh II, up to six different individual are said to have reigned, these are [[Ardashir III]], [[Shahrbaraz]], [[Borandukht]], [[Shapur-i Shahrvaraz]], [[Azarmidokht]] and [[Farrukh Hormizd]]. Negations continued with Shahrbaraz being the real power. Antiochus records that Heraclius made an agreement with Ardashir III with Shahrbaraz acting as intermediary,{{rp|187 }} [[Nikephoros I of Constantinople|Nikephoros]] gives a date of July 629 at Arabissos.{{rp|185}} Walter Emil Kaegi sees this July 629 meeting as representing an earlier negotiation with Shahrbaraz preceding the death of Kavadh II.{{rp|187 }} Nikephoros exaggerated and confused the record by claiming that Hormizd succeeded Kavadh II. Claiming Hormizd sent his son to Heraclius' court.{{rp|185}} Heraclius was in Constantinople in 629 where he issued a "novel", or law, that went into effect on 1 April 629.{{rp|186}} At Arabissos Heraclius and Shahrbaraz would agree on new borders.{{rp|188}} To seal the deal Shahrbaraz's son [[Niketas the Persian|Niketas]] and another of his brothers came to live at the Byzantine court, having been held for a time in central Mesopotamia practically as hostages. They arrived along with the True Cross. The Holy Sponge was attached to the cross in a special ceremony in Constantinople on 14 September 629. The Holy Lance followed reaching Constantinople on 28 October 629. It is probable that at this time, Niketas converted to Christianity; as he was his father's heir-apparent, this opened the prospect of the Christianization of Persia should Shahrbaraz be able to maintain his power there.{{rp|188–189, 206}} Heraclius would not have entered Jerusalem while the Persian troop presence persisted. Heraclius brother [[Theodore (brother of Heraclius)|Theodore]] had encounter resistance at Edessa and Heraclius would not have exposed himself to similar danger. Shahrbaraz had [[Ardashir III]] assassinated and took control of the Persian Empire from 27 April 630 to 9 June 630.{{rp|185}} The 630 date would also have the advantage of matching the date for the Fast of Heraclius.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=aScNMZWlxYUC&pg=PA134&dq=Egypt+jews+630&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lLMsU4DTDanlyQGliIGgBA&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Egypt%20jews%20630&f=false |title=Arab Conquest of Egypt and the Last Thirty Years of the Roman Dominion |year=1902 |author=Alfred Joshua Butler |publisher=Clarendon Press |page=134 |accessdate= 21 March 2014}} ===Discourse=== ====Reconciliation attempts==== Heraclius came as victor into the country and the Jews of Tiberias and Nazareth, under the leadership of Benjamin of Tiberias, surrendered and asked for his protection. It is said that Benjamin even accompanied Heraclius on his voyage to Jerusalem and Benjamin was persuaded to convert, Benjamin obtained a general pardon for himself and the Jews. He was baptized in [[Nablus]] in the house of Eustathios, an influential Christian. However once Heraclius reached Jerusalem he was persuaded to go back on his promise to Benjamin of Tiberias.{{cite web |url = http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=RELEVANCE&inPS=true&prodId=GVRL&userGroupName=imcpl1111&tabID=T003&searchId=R5&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&contentSegment=&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm¤tPosition=6&contentSet=GALE%7CCX2587502507&&docId=GALE | title = Encyclopedia Judaica - Benjamin of Tiberias |date = 2007 |editors= Michael Berenbaum and Fred Skolnik. Vol. 3. 2nd ed |website = Gale Virtual Reference Library |publisher = Detroit: Macmillan Reference USA | page= 362 | accessdate= 14 January 2014}} According to [[Patriarch Eutychius of Alexandria|Eutychius]] (887-940), the Christians population and monks of Jerusalem convinced the Emperor to break his word.{{rp| 48–49}} Some modern scholars ascribe the story of the "Oath of Heraclius" to the realm of legend, doubting that Heraclius ever made such a promise,{{rp| 38}} instead ascribing this as a product of later apologists.{{cite book |first=David |last=Lewis |title=God's Crucible: Islam and the Making of Europe, 570–1215 |publisher=Norton |year=2008 |page=69 |isbn=9780393064728 }} ====Massacre of the Jews==== Jews were expelled from Jerusalem and were not allowed to settle within a three-mile radius. A general massacre of the Jewish population ensued. The massacre devastated the Jewish communities of the [[Galilee]] and Jerusalem. Only those Jews who could flee to the mountains or Egypt are said to have been spared.{{rp| 38}} In atonement for the violation of the emperor's oath to the Jews, the monks are said to have pledged themselves to a yearly fast, which is still observed by the [[Copt]]s,{{cite book |url = http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/3877-byzantine-expire#anchor6| title = Jewish Encyclopedia BYZANTINE EXPIRE: Heraclius| publisher = Jewish Encyclopedia| year = 1906 | quote= In atonement for the violation of an oath to the Jews, the monks pledged themselves to a fast, which the Copts still observe; while the Syrians and the Melchite Greeks ceased to keep it after the death of Heraclius; Elijah of Nisibis ("Beweis der Wahrheit des Glaubens," translation by Horst, p. 108, Colmar, 1886) mocks at the observance.|accessdate= 28 January 2015}}{{cite book |title= Heraclius, Emperor of Byzantium|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=tlNlFZ_7UhoC&pg=PA205&dq=Heraclius+massacre+Galilee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uMzJVLGcM8WbNvTTgdgI&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Heraclius%20massacre%20Galilee&f=false| author = Walter Emil Kaegi| publisher = Cambridge University Press |year = 2003|page = 205|accessdate=28 January 2015}} called the Fast of Heraclius.{{cite book|author1=Abu Salih the Armenian|author2=Abu al-Makarim|authorlink2=Abu al-Makarim|editor=Basil Thomas Alfred Evetts|title="History of Churches and Monasteries", Abu Salih the Armenian c. 1266 - Part 7 of Anecdota Oxoniensia: Semitic series Anecdota oxoniensia. [Semitic series--pt. VII]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RCJiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA39|year=1895|publisher=Clarendon Press|pages=39–|id=|quote=the emperor Heraclius, on his way to Jerusalem, promised his protection to the Jews of Palestine. (Abu Salih the Armenian, Abu al-Makarim, ed. Evetts 1895, p. 39, Part 7 of Anecdota Oxoniensia: Semitic series Anecdota oxoniensia. Semitic series--pt. VII) (Abu Salih the Armenian was just the Book's owner, the author is actually Abu al-Makarim.)|authormask=|trans-title=|format=|origyear=|oclc=|doi=|bibcode=|laysummary=|laydate=}} ====Conversion policy of Heraclius==== In 628, Heraclius reportedly rescinded a decision made by his brother which would have exterminated the Jews of Edessa for supporting the Persians. Robert Bonfil suggests that Heraclius’ change of heart in 630 cannot be separated from the "Jewish Question" and the anti-Jewish world view ubiquitous to Christian thought at that time. He sees the decision as being based more on politics than religion.{{rp| 81–84 }} Heraclius is one of the few Byzantine emperors to have had an imperial conversion campaign. The rarity of such campaigns is thought to be due to Christian theological constraints. In Christian apocalyptic literature, some Jews must remain until the end of time.{{rp| 878 }} Christian theologians of the time also had other core theological reasons for rejecting the forced conversion of Jews.{{rp| 84–85}} In another legend, Heraclius' astrologers are said to have revealed to him that a circumcised people would conquer his empire.{{cite book |title= Heraclius, Emperor of Byzantium|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=tlNlFZ_7UhoC&pg=PA205&dq=Heraclius+massacre+Galilee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uMzJVLGcM8WbNvTTgdgI&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Heraclius%20massacre%20Galilee&f=false| author = Walter Emil Kaegi| publisher = Cambridge University Press |year = 2003|page = 194 }} Heraclius set out to forcible convert the Jews of the Byzantine Empire, reportedly advising his friend Dagobert, king of the Franks, to do likewise.{{cite book |url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/3877-byzantine-expire#anchor6 |encyclopedia=[[Jewish Encyclopedia]] |title=Byzantine Empire: Heraclius |publisher=Funk and Wagnalls |year=1906 |accessdate= 28 January 2015}} ==In apocalyptic literature== The events of the Persian-Byzantine struggle in the Levant and the consequent Arab conquest inspired several apocalyptic Jewish writings of the early Middle Ages. Helping to popularize the idea of a war messiah, the [[Messiah ben Joseph]], who would die paving the way for the Messiah ben David.{{rp|168–171}}{{cite web|last=Blidstein|first=Prof. Dr. Gerald J.|title=Messiah in Rabbinic Thought|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0014_0_13744.html|work=MESSIAH|publisher=Jewish Virtual Library and Encyclopaedia Judaica 2008 The Gale Group|accessdate=2 December 2012}} Among these are the [[Apocalypse of Zerubbabel]], which is partially attributed to the events between the Persian conquest of [[Palaestina Prima|Palaestina]] and subsequent [[Muslim conquest of Syria]].{{cite book |title=History of Messianic Speculation in Israel |first=Abba Hillel |last=Silver |pages=49 |chapter=II The Mohammedan Period |year=2003 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=0-7661-3514-4}} The [[Tiburtine Sibyl]] records that the Jews of the Byzantine Empire would be converted in one hundred and twenty years, seeming to refer to these occurrences, since about one hundred and twenty years elapsed from the time of the Persian war under Anastasius, in 505, to the victory of Heraclius in 628. Some scholars see similarities between these Christian works and their Jewish counterparts.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lrKRgCv2uE0C&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=Otot+ha-Ma%C5%A1iah&source=bl&ots=ZnakdJYa4U&sig=KgxKwEIeJavQCn80gdo9CK2YuEs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xwaIVI3VBYWhNtDEgPAE&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Otot%20ha-Ma%C5%A1iah&f=false | title = Judaism and Imperial Ideology in Late Antiquity | pages =55–58| author= Alexei Sivertsev | publisher =Cambridge University Press| year = 2011| accessdate = 17 December 2014}}{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nw-rR_Skb-cC&pg=PA180&lpg=PA180&dq=Tiburtine+sibyl+Heraclius&source=bl&ots=mVfyVo_8j9&sig=qX4UeZd0m6g7_Bv6tZOqPoxdZd4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Rb3KVPKTO8qmgwTwxYHIBg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Tiburtine%20sibyl%20Heraclius&f=false| title = The Byzantine Apocalyptic Tradition| pages =180–181| author= Paul Julius Alexander| publisher = University of California Press| year = 1985| accessdate = 29 January 2015}} ==Aftermath== Following the defeat of the Persian Empire the territory would not remain in Byzantine hands for long. By 638, the Arabs would conquer Jerusalem.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=c788wWR_bLwC&pg=PA525&dq=arab+638+jerusalem&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bQhyVePyD4ORsAXVmIOQDQ&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=arab%20638%20jerusalem&f=false| title = Late Antiquity: A Guide to the Postclassical World| authors = Glen Warren Bowersock, Peter Brown, Oleg Grabar|publisher = Harvard University Press| year = 1999|page =525}} Caesarea would remain under Byzantine control until 640.{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pckUkJIHjiQC&pg=PA628&dq=Caesarea+Maritima+Persians&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3fEsU_GGGuWsyAHhuYHgAw&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=614&f=false| title = Caesarea Maritima: A Retrospective After Two Millennia |editors= Avnēr Rabbān, Kenneth G. Holum|publisher = BRILL| year = 1996|page =187| accessdate= 21 March 2014}} The Arab Islamic Empire under Caliph [[Umar]] conquered the lands of [[Mesopotamia]], the Levant, and Egypt. ==Demographic impact== Some historians believe the war reduced and weakened the Christian population not just in Jerusalem but across the Near East, allowing the success of the following Arab invasion. However, over the past thirty years the archaeological evidence has not supported the ancient manuscripts which record the devastation of the Christian community in Jerusalem.{{rp| 353}} Jerusalem is said to have been burnt down. However, neither wide spread burning nor destruction of churches have been found in the archaeological record. Despite the claims of large scale destruction, the archaeological evidence does not reveal layers of destruction associated with the Persian conquest. There was also no hard evidence found for the widespread destruction of churches. A significant number of burial sites were allocated according to Strategius. A mass burial grave at [[Mamilla]] cave was discovered in 1989 by Israeli [[archeologist]] [[Ronny Reich]], near the site where Strategius recorded the massacre took place. The human remains were in poor condition containing a minimum of 526 individuals. Other mass burial sites have also been found although they cannot be accurately dated to the Persian conquest of Jerusalem. Yet, excavations of Jerusalem show a continuous habitation in Jerusalem neighborhoods and essentially little impact of population during the period of Persian governorship. As stated by archaeologist Gideon Avni: :''... all excavated sites in Jerusalem show a clear pattern of continuity, with no evidence for destruction by the Persian conquest of 614 or the Arab conquest of 636.'' Demographic continuity might have resulted from population exchange by the victorious Jewish rebels, but apparently also the Christian habitation remained relatively constant, despite the disturbance by the Persian conquest, and no significant impact on the population of Jerusalem was made during the following period of Sassanid dominance. ==See also== * [[List of conflicts in the Near East]] * [[Jewish-Roman wars]] 66–136 CE * [[Jewish revolt against Gallus]] 352 CE * [[Samaritan Revolts]] 484–572 CE * [[Yehud Medinata]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jewish Revolt Against Heraclius}} [[Category:610s in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:620s in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:7th-century conflicts]] [[Category:7th-century Judaism]] [[Category:Ancient Jewish Persian history]] [[Category:Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628]] [[Category:Holy Land during Byzantine rule]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:Jewish rebellions]] [[Category:Medieval Jerusalem]] [[Category:Religion in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:610s in the Sasanian Empire]] [[Category:620s in the Sasanian Empire]] [[Category:Judaism in the Sasanian Empire]]

The '''Left Column''' (German: ''Kolonne Links'') was an [[agitprop]] theater troupe during the 1920s and 1930s. The troupe worked in support of the [[Workers International Relief]] (WIR). During the Nazi era, some of the group went into exile in the Soviet Union, where some of the members were arrested by the [[NKVD|Soviet secret police]] in the [[Great Purge]] and in connection with the [[Hitler Youth Conspiracy]].
== History == In its early years, the group consisted of nine people, none of whom had any theatrical training, a pianist and a driver. The [[Berlin]] troupe<ref>C.D. Innes, [https://books.google.com/books?id=J7Y8AAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA55&ots=bZUim1y9PE&dq=&pg=PA55#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Erwin Piscator's political theatre: the development of modern German drama''] Cambridge University Press (1972), p. 55. {{ISBN|0-521-08456-3}}. Retrieved November 29, 2011</ref> was one of the most highly praised agitprop troupes in Germany,<ref>Ewan MacColl, [http://www.wcml.org.uk/contents/activists/ewan-maccoll/theatre/theatre-of-action/#pagetop "Theatre of Action"] Working Class Movement Library. Retrieved November 29, 2011</ref> despite its lack of training.
Hans Hauska joined the troupe in late summer 1930.<ref name="phelps">Thomas Phelps, [http://www.uni-giessen.de/~g51092/LinkswodasHerz.html "Links wo das Herz ist"] Justus Liebig University Giessen (October 27–28, 1997). Retrieved November 29, 2011 {{de icon}}</ref>
In 1931, the Left Column were rewarded with a tour in the [[Soviet Union]] for five weeks for having gained 16,000 new members for the WIR.<ref name="phelps" /> On their return, they discovered that several of their performances in Germany were cancelled because a March 28, 1931 decree from the [[President of Germany (1919–1945)|Reichspräsident]] to combat violence led to a local prohibition against agitprop theater assemblies.<ref name="phelps" /> Six members then left Germany, embarking on a 4-month trip by boat and train across [[Siberia]] back to Moscow.<ref name="phelps" /> In 1933, under [[Gustav von Wangenheim]]'s leadership, they established the German Left Column Theater with members of "Troupe 31", another agitprop theater group.<ref name="phelps" />
In 1935, troupe members [[Helmut Damerius]] and Bruno Schmidtsdorf, were in Wangenheim's 1935 anti-Nazi film, ''Kämpfer''. Schmidtsdorf played the lead role,<ref name="hs-1">Hans Schafranek, [http://www.iwk-online.de/2001-1_schafranek.html "Kontingentierte 'Volksfeinde' und 'Agenturarbeit'"] Internationale wissenschaftliche Korrespondenz zur Geschichte der deutschen Arbeiterbewegung (January 2001). Retrieved November 26, 2011 {{de icon}}</ref> Fritz Lemke, and Hauska wrote the music.
Beginning in 1935, the NKVD began arresting members of the troupe in the Great Purge.<ref name="phelps-n39,40" /> All those arrested were members who had arrived in Moscow after 1932. Arrested members included Hans Hauska on November 20, 1937.<ref name="phelps-n39,40">Thomas Phelps (1997), [http://www.uni-giessen.de/~g51092/LinkswodasHerz.html See footnotes 39 and 40]</ref> On February 5, 1938, Kurt Ahrendt, Karl Oefelein and Schmidtsdorf were arrested, charged with starting a branch of the [[Hitler Youth]], and were executed three weeks later.<ref name="phelps-n39,40" /> On March 17, 1938, Helmut Damerius, once a leader of the troupe, was arrested and sent to a [[gulag]] in [[Siberia]]. His sentence ended in 1946, after which he was exiled to [[Kazakhstan]] and forced to remain another eight years.<ref name="epstein">Catherine Epstein, [https://books.google.com/books?id=MHjpAWwF-zQC&lpg=PA57&ots=Xzezx0aalN&dq=&pg=PA57#v=onepage&q&f=false "The Last Revolutionaries: German Communists and Their Century''] President and Fellows of Harvard College (2003), p. 57. {{ISBN|0-674-01045-0}}. Retrieved November 30, 2011</ref> Hauska, after four years in custody, and sentenced in a Nazi court on August 18, 1939 to one and a half years at hard labor in a [[Prisons in Germany#Previous types of prisons|Zuchthaus]],<ref name="phelps" /> was returned to the Nazis on December 5, 1940 under the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]].<ref name="phelps-n39,40" /> Other arrested members were [[Hans Klering]]; Max Mielke, who arrived in Moscow in 1932, was arrested in 1938 and never heard from again; Albert Wolff; and Max (Samuel) Katzenellenbogen, a former member of the troupe in Berlin, who fled to Moscow after having been arrested by the Gestapo.<ref name="phelps-n39,40" /> He was arrested by the NKVD in 1937 and never heard from again.<ref name="phelps-n39,40" />
Damerius survived his imprisonment,<ref name="fict-220">Hans Schafranek, Natalia Musienko (2003), [https://books.google.com/books?id=8yorTJl1QEoC&lpg=PA220&ots=IQbXKWcxE-&dq=&pg=PA220#v=onepage&q&f=false "The Fictitious 'Hiter-Jugend' of the Moscow NKVD"] in: Barry McLoughlin, Kevin McDermott (Eds.), ''Stalin's Terror: High Politics and Mass Repression in the Soviet Union.'' Palgrave MacMillan (2003), p. 220. {{ISBN|1-4039-0119-8}} Retrieved December 1, 2011</ref> as did Klering, who returned to Germany in 1946 and became a co-founder of [[DEFA]].<ref name="phelps-n39,40" /> Damerius was unable to leave the Soviet Union until 1956.<ref name="epstein" />
== Notable members == * [[Helmut Damerius]] * [[Hans Hauska]] * [[Hans Klering]] * [[Gustav von Wangenheim]]
== See also == * [[Blue Blouse]]
== Further reading == * Christine Kanzler, "Vom Kulturrevolutionär zum 'Volksfeind'. Hans Hauska und die 'Kolonne Links'" in: Hans Schafranek (Ed.), ''Die Betrogenen. Österreicher als Opfer stalinistischen Terrors in der Sowjetunion'', Vienna (1991) p. 48ff {{de icon}} * Hermann Weber, "Weiße Flecken" in der Geschichte. Die KPD-Opfer der Stalinschen Säuberungen und ihre Rehabilitierung, Frankfurt am Main (1989), p. 86ff {{de icon}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0027388/ ''Der Kampf'' (1936), U.S. release of Gustav von Wangenheim's film, ''Kämpfer''] Internet Movie Database. (Original Russian title: ''Bortsy'')

{{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox theatre | name = Liverpool Playhouse | image = Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool 2018-2.jpg | image_size = 250 | image_alt = | caption = Liverpool Playhouse | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Merseyside | pushpin_map_caption= Location in Merseyside | address = [[Williamson Square]] | city = [[Liverpool]] | country = England | designation = [[listed building|Listed Building Grade II*]] | coordinates = {{coord|53.4064|-2.9826|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = Edward Davies, Harry Percival,
Stanley Adshead,
Hall, O'Donahue and Wilson | owner = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust | tenant = | operator = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust | capacity = | type = Theatre | opened = 1866 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = Star Music Hall,
Star Theatre of Varieties,
Liverpool Repertory Theatre | production = | currentuse = | website = [http://www.everymanplayhouse.com/playhouse] }} The '''Liverpool Playhouse''' is a theatre in [[Williamson Square]] in the city of [[Liverpool]], England. It originated in 1866 as a [[music hall]], and in 1911 developed into a [[repertory]] theatre. As such it nurtured the early careers of many actors and actresses, some of whom went on to achieve national and international reputations. Architectural changes have been made to the building over the years, the latest being in 1968 when a modern-style extension was added to the north of the theatre. In 1999 a trust was formed, joining the management of the Playhouse with that of the [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]]. ==History== The present theatre on the site was designed by Edward Davies, and opened in 1866. It replaced an earlier theatre called the Star Concert Hall. The present theatre was originally named the Star Music Hall.{{Citation | url = http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Liverpool/PlayhouseTheatreLiverpool.htm| title = Playhouse Theatre, Williamson Square, Liverpool F.C.| accessdate = 14 August 2011| publisher = Matthew Lloyd}} In 1895 its name was changed to the Star Theatre of Varieties. The theatre was improved in 1898 by Harry Percival with a new auditorium and foyer, and electricity was installed. In 1911 the Liverpool Repertory Theatre Limited was established, with [[Basil Dean]] as its "controller and producer". The company could not afford to build a new theatre, and bought the Star Theatre for £28,000 {{Inflation|UK|28000|1911|r=-4|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}).{{Inflation-fn|UK|df=y}} This made it the first [[repertory]] in Britain to own the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] of a theatre. The company spent a further £4,000 ({{Inflation|UK|4000|1911|r=-4|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}) on redesigning and modernising the theatre.{{Citation| last = Iles| first = Paul| title = Green Room versus Board Room: Liverpool Playhouse and Business Modelling for Resident Theatres| publisher = The Laughing Audience| url = http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/business_models.html| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090304170514/http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/business_models.html| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 4 March 2009| accessdate = 14 August 2011}} The auditorium and the basement foyer were redesigned by Stanley Adshead, the Professor of Civic Design at the Liverpool School of Architecture.{{Citation | last =Pollard| first =Richard | last2 = Pevsner | first2 = Nikolaus | author2-link =Nikolaus Pevsner| series= The Buildings of England|title =Lancashire: Liverpool and the South-West | publisher =[[Yale University Press]] | year =2006 | location =New Haven and London | page = 301| isbn =0-300-10910-5 }} The theatre was for many years managed by [[Maud Carpenter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sarsfieldmemorialsliverpool.co.uk/memorial-maud-farrington-nee-carpenter/|title=Memorial to Maud Farrington nee Carpenter|publisher=Sarsfieldmemorialsliverpool.co.uk|accessdate=8 March 2016}} The theatre was renamed the Liverpool Repertory Theatre, and in 1916 renamed again, as the Liverpool Playhouse. Minor structural alterations were made to the theatre in 1961 and in 1966. In 1968 a modern-style extension was added to the north of the theatre to accommodate new foyers, bars, dressing rooms and a workshop. In the 1990s the theatre company went into liquidation. In 1999 the Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust Limited was established as a charity, and the theatre re-opened.{{Citation | url = http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1081229&SubsidiaryNumber=0| title = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust Ltd| accessdate = 14 August 2011| publisher = [[Charity Commission]]}} It is managed jointly with the [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]] by [[Liverpool City Council]].{{Citation | last = Pye| first = Ken| year = 2011| title = Discover Liverpool| publication-place = Liverpool| publisher = Trinity Mirror Media| page = 66| isbn = 978-1-906802-90-5}} ==Artistes== As a repertory company, the theatre has been involved in the careers of actors and actresses who have later achieved wide fame. [[Noël Coward]] and [[Gertrude Lawrence]] worked with the company as child actors. Other artistes who gained experience at the theatre include [[Robert Donat]], [[Lilian Braithwaite]], [[Cecil Parker]], [[John Gregson]], [[Clive Brook]], [[C. Aubrey Smith]], [[Richard Burton]], [[Michael Redgrave]], [[Diana Wynyard]], [[Rex Harrison]], [[Patricia Routledge]], [[Anthony Hopkins]], and [[Richard Briers]]. ==Architecture== ===Older section=== The exterior of the older part of the theatre is [[stucco]]ed, and it has a [[slate]] roof. Its entrance front faces Williamson Square. It has seven [[bay (architecture)|bays]] and is in three storeys. The central three bays project forward and are surmounted by a broken [[pediment]]. On the ground floor the central bays contain three entrances, separated by pillars, which lead to a recessed porch. Over each entrance is an [[architrave]] containing a [[fanlight]]. The lateral bays contain two round-headed and one flat-headed entrance on each side, over which are three blind round windows. In the middle storey, the bays are separated by [[pilaster]]s. The three central bays each have a [[baluster|balustrade]] and a window with a [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] containing a roundel. Each of the three lateral bays contains a window with a [[cornice]], and a round window above it. Along the top storey are [[Oculus|oculi]] between panelled pilasters. On the summit of each of the two lateral bays is a [[cupola]] on a short [[Tuscan order|Tuscan]] [[colonnade]]. Inside the older part of the theatre are two balconies supported by [[cast iron]] columns. The interior is decorated in [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek Revival]] style.{{NHLE |num= 1218642|desc= Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool F.C.|accessdate= 20 August 2013|mode=cs2|ps=none}} ===Newer section=== The newer section is constructed in concrete, and largely faced by glass. On the ground floor are entrance doors. Above this, the building is based around three cylinders. The largest of these starts at the first floor and rises through two storeys. It is [[cantilever]]ed from a central column. To the left is a smaller cylinder, cantilevered from a separate column, interlocking with the larger cylinder. Inside the whole is a hollow column containing the stairs. ===Assessment and critique=== The theatre is recorded in the [[National Heritage List for England]] as a designated Grade II* [[Listed building#England and Wales|listed building]], having been designated on 14 March 1975. In its description, the list quotes the ''[[Architects' Journal]]'' of 1968 which says of the older section that it is "significant as an early and rare work by one of the pioneers of the Liverpool School of Architecture, in the Grecian style favoured by the school at that date", and of the newer section that it is "a brilliant concept, joyously realised, which exploits asymmetrical volumes and ever varying spaces yet achieves unity and also balance with the adjoining [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] façade".{{Citation | publication-date = 4 December 1968| title = | periodical = [[Architects' Journal]]| page = 1327}} In the ''[[Pevsner Architectural Guides|Buildings of England]]'' series the architectural historians Richard Pollard and [[Nikolaus Pevsner]] say of the newer section that it is "a spectacular composition" which creates an atmosphere of excitement and anticipation, exactly right for a theatre foyer". ==See also== {{Portal|Merseyside}} *[[Architecture of Liverpool]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool}} *[http://www.everymanplayhouse.com Official website of the Playhouse and Everyman theatres] {{Liverpool B&S}} [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in Liverpool]] [[Category:Theatres in Liverpool]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Liverpool]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1866]] [[Category:Producing theatres in England]] [[Category:1866 establishments in England]]

{{Other uses|Mikhaylovsky (disambiguation){{!}}Mikhaylovsky}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox building | name = Mikhailovsky Theatre | alternate_names = | status = | image = Spb 06-2012 MichaelTheatre.jpg | image_alt = | caption = | location = [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]] | address = 1, [[Arts Square (Saint Petersburg)|Arts Square]] | coordinates = | architect = | start_date = | completion_date = | renovation_date = | former_names = Ex-Mikhailovsky Theatre (1918-1920)
State Academic Comic Opera Theatre (1920)
Maly Operny Teatr (1921-1926)
Leningrad State Academic Maly Opera Theatre (1926-1989)
Modest Mussorgsky (1989-2007) | url = {{URL|https://mikhailovsky.ru/}} }} The '''Mikhailovsky Theatre''' ({{lang-ru|Миха́йловский теа́тр}}) is one of [[Russia]]'s oldest [[opera]] and [[ballet]] houses. It was founded in 1833 and is situated in a historical building on 1, [[Arts Square (Saint Petersburg)|Arts Square]] in [[Saint Petersburg]]. It is named after [[Grand Duke Michael Pavlovich of Russia]]. == History == === Before 1917 === The theatre was established in 1833 by decree of Tsar [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]. Before the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|1917 Revolution]], the Mikhailovsky did not have its own resident company. Performances were given either by a French company, hired by the Russian Imperial Theatres, or at the end of the century by the [[Mariinsky Theatre]] and [[Alexandrinsky Theatre]] companies. Most of the great French actors of the period performed at the theatre, including [[Jeanne Sylvanie Arnould-Plessy]], [[Rachel Félix]], [[Lucien Guitry]] and [[Sarah Bernhardt]], as well as singers such as [[Hortense Schneider]]. Both classical and contemporary authors and composers had their works produced to great acclaim in French. Plays by [[Molière]], [[Victor Hugo]], [[Victorien Sardou]], and [[Alexandre Dumas, fils]] and [[operettas]] by [[Jacques Offenbach]] were praised by the intelligentsia and the Russian aristocracy, such as [[Tolstoy]] and [[Tchaikovsky]]. When the [[Bolshevik]]s took power the French company was forced to leave Russia, and in 1917 the Mikhailovsky Theatre was closed. === Communist era === On March 6, 1918 the theatre was reopened as an opera theatre. Shortly afterwards the Mikhailovsky started changing its names: in 1918–20 it was called the Ex-Mikhailovsky Theatre, in 1920 it was renamed to the State Academic Comic Opera Theatre, in 1921 the theatre changed its name to the Maly Operny Teatr (Maly Opera Theatre), in 1926 it got the name of the Leningrad State Academic Maly Opera Theatre, MALEGOT for short. New management and artists followed. From 1920 to 1930 the Maly Operny Teatr established itself as one of the leading experimental stages in Russian new [[musical theatre]]. [[Shostakovich]] made his debut at the Maly Operny: [[Samuil Samosud]] conducted world premiere performances of his ''[[The Nose (opera)|The Nose]]'' and ''[[Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District (opera)|Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District]]'', the famous [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] production of ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]'' was staged there, and the [[world premiere]] of [[Prokofiev]]'s epic opera ''[[War and Peace (Prokofiev)|War and Peace]]'' took place on the theatre's stage on June 12, 1946. === 1930: Creation of the Ballet Company === In 1930s Russian choreographer [[Fyodor Lopukhov]] founded the ballet company of the Theatre. The first ballet premiere, ''[[Les millions d'Arlequin|Harlequinade]]'', choreographed by Lopukhov, took place on June 6, 1933.{{cite web|url=http://www.citywalls.ru/house826.html?s=nhu3hgcosjoabru2p062mosrj6 |title=Михайловский театр - Театр Оперы и балета им. Мусоргского, Классицизм, Архитектор Брюллов А. П., Росси К. И., Кавос А. К., Искусств пл., 1, Инженерная ул., 1 |language=ru |website=Citywalls.ru |date=2012-10-28 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} === The 2000s revival === From 1989 to 2007, the theatre bore the name of [[Modest Mussorgsky]], subsequently returning to its original name the Mikhailovsky Theatre.[http://www.mikhailovsky.ru/theatre/ History of the Mikhaylovsky Theatre], official site. Retrieved 10 August 2008. {{ru icon}} In 2007, in what was seen as a controversial move, Russian businessman [[Vladimir Kekhman]] was appointed as General Director of the theatre. Vladimir Kekhman's strategy was to spend prolific amounts of money on ballet stars to build the Theatre's popularity.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russia-is-rocked-by-a-bolshoi-revolution-6263239.html|title=Russia is rocked by a Bolshoi revolution|website=Independent.co.uk|date=17 November 2011|author=Shaun Walker|accessdate=1 October 2018}} He built a business-based organizational structures to the Ballet, donated 1 billion [[rouble]]s ($40m US) for renovation of the building, and invited [[Elena Obraztsova]] and [[Farouk Ruzimatov]] to coordinate the artistic revival of the Mikhailovsky.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/jan/01/mikhailovsky-ballet-bolshoi|title=Who’s pulling the strings in Russia’s Ballet Revolution?|website=Theguardian.com|date=1 January 2012|author=Luke Jennings|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In 2007, Elena Obraztsova was appointed Artistic Director of the Mikhailovsky Opera and Farouk Ruzimatov became Artistic Director of the Mikhailovsky Ballet. However, Obraztsova resigned in 2008 and Ruzimatov in 2009. From 2009 both Obraztsova and Ruzimatov held a seat on the Artistic Committee of the Theatre. The ballet company of the Mikhailovsky Theatre made its London debut in July 2008 in [[London Coliseum]] arranged by the British ex-dancer [[Gavin Roebuck]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}. This season helped bring the company international recognition and led to a nomination for the Best Foreign Dance Company Award at the National Dance Awards in 2008, though Mikhailovsky lost out to the [[New York City Ballet]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaldanceawards.com/dance2008/foreign_dance.htm |title=National Dance Awards Best Foreign Dance Company |website=Nationaldanceawards.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} In March 2009, [[Mikhail Messerer]] was appointed Ballet Master in Chief of the Theater. For the Mikhailovsky, Messerer staged numerous ballets, including ''[[Swan Lake]]'', ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'', ''[[Flames of Paris]]'', ''[[Laurencia (ballet)|Laurencia]]'', ''[[Cinderella]]'' and ''[[Le Corsaire]]''. In 2009 - 2011 Peter Feranec was the Theatre's Musical Director. [[Mikhail Tatarnikov]] began his tenure as the Theatre’s musical director in 2012 (he resigned in October 2018). The Mikhailovsky Ballet returned to London in 2010, again arranged with Gavin Roebuck{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}. From 2011 till 2013 [[Nacho Duato]] worked as the Mikhailovsky Ballet's Artistic Director, with Messerer as the Theatre's Ballet Master in Chief. Several of Duato ballets received their world premieres at the Mikhailovsky. Under Mikhail Messerer's leadership the Mikhailovsky Ballet has won the Best Ballet Company award by the British Critics' Circle for it's 3rd London season in 2013. Also in 2013, the Mikhailovsky Opera made its debut at the Savonlinna Opera Festival,{{cite web|url=http://www.operafestival.fi/news/Mikhailovsky-Theatre-to-perform-Eugene-Onegin-and--Un-ballo-in-maschera-at-the-Savonlinna-Opera-Festival/3qe3bat3/77d5f26e-4801-4cf9-9409-01c3006d872b |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109134630/http://www.operafestival.fi/news/Mikhailovsky-Theatre-to-perform-Eugene-Onegin-and--Un-ballo-in-maschera-at-the-Savonlinna-Opera-Festival/3qe3bat3/77d5f26e-4801-4cf9-9409-01c3006d872b |archivedate=2013-11-09 |df= }} and, in November 2014, the Mikhailovsky Ballet debuted in the US at New York's [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]]. In October 2012, Vladimir Kekhman was declared bankrupt at London's High Court of Justice, but he assured that the operation of the Mikhailovsky Theatre was not at risk.{{cite web|url=https://theartsdesk.com/dance/bankruptcy-wont-stop-ballet-0|title=Bankruptcy won't stop the ballet|website=Theartdesk.com|date=28 January 2013|author=Ismene Brown|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In April 2013, top ballet dancer [[Natalia Osipova]] left the company to join [[The Royal Ballet]] in London, after she had made the headlines in December 2011 for choosing the Mikhailosky Theatre over the [[Bolshoi Theatre]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/dance/9981660/Natalia-Osipova-to-leave-Russia-for-London-principal-dancer-role.html|title=Natalia Osipova to leave Russia for London principal dancer role|website=Telegraph.co.uk|date=9 April 2013|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In December 2013, Altynai Asylmuratova became Adviser to General Director of the Theatre (she resigned in March 2014). In 2013 Vasily Barkhatov was appointed Artistic Director of the Mikhailovsky Opera (he resigned in 2014). In 2014 Vasily Petrenko became the Theatre's Principal Guest Conductor (he resigned in 2015). In 2015, the tenor [[Neil Shicoff]] was appointed Chief of the Mikhailovsky Opera,{{cite web|url=https://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2015/5/News/Shicoff_Chief_of_Opera_Mikhailovsky_Theatre.html|title=St. Petersburg’s Mikhailovsky Theatre Appoints Tenor Neil Shicoff as Company's Chief of Opera|website=Operanews.com|date=5 May 2015|accessdate=1 October 2018}} and from July 2017 till July 2018, the bass Paata Burchuladze was the Chief of the Mikhailovsky Opera. Mikhail Messerer resigned from the Theatre in September 2018. == Ballet Company == '''Principals''' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} ''Ballerinas'' *Ekaterina Borchenko *Angelina Vorontsova *Irina Perren *[[Polina Semionova|Polina Semionova (guest principal)]] *Oksana Shadrukhina {{col-2-of-2}} ''Men'' *[[Ivan Vasiliev]] *Ivan Zaytsev *Victor Lebedev *Leonid Sarafanov *Mikhail Sivakov *[[Friedemann Vogel|Friedemann Vogel (guest principal)]] *Marat Shemiunov {{col-end}} '''First Soloists''' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} ''Women'' *Svetlana Bednenko *Irina Kosheleva *Anastasia Soboleva *Olga Stepanova *Elvira Khabibullina *Sabina Yapparova {{col-2-of-2}} ''Men'' *Andrey Kasyanenko *Ernest Latypov *Julian MacKay *Anton Ploom *Andrey Yakhnyuk {{col-end}} '''Second Soloists''' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} ''Women'' *Valeria Zapasnikova *Anna Kuligina *Andrea Laššáková *Tatiana Miltseva {{col-2-of-2}} ''Men'' *Mikhail Venshchikov *Alexey Kuznetsov *Alexey Malakhov *Denis Morozov *Alexander Omar *Sergey Strelkov *Denis Tolmachov *Vladimir Tsal {{col-end}} '''Coryphees''' ''Women'' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} *Maria Dmitriyenko *Irina Zhalovskaya *Veronika Ignatyeva *Yulia Kamilov *Kristina Makhviladze *Elena Nikiforova {{col-2-of-2}} *Anna Novosyolova *Asthik Ogannesyan *Ella Persson *Olga Semyonova *Mariam Ugrekhelidze {{col-end}} ''Men'' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} *Andrey Bregvadze *Andrey Lapshanov *Andrey Masloboyev *Nikita Nazarov {{col-2-of-2}} *Elvis Nudo *Roman Petukhov *Maxim Podosyonov {{col-end}} '''Corps de Ballet''' *57 women *24 men '''Repetiteurs''' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} *Zhanna Ayupova *Svetlana Efremova *Tatiana Zimina *Evgenia Kostyleva *Regina Kuzmichova {{col-2-of-2}} *Kirill Myasnikov *Alla Osipenko *Evgeny Popov *Anna Razenko *Natalia Tsyplakova {{col-end}} '''Repertoire''' {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-5}} *[[Don Quixote]] - '''Monterey Car Week''' is a week in August in which a number of car-related events are held in and around [[Monterey, California]].
==Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance== {{main|Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance}} The Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance is held on the final Sunday of Monterey Car Week. It is a car show showing the most elegant and notable vehicles in the world. The proceeds of the show support charities.
==Rolex Monterey Motorsports Reunion== {{main|Rolex Monterey Motorsports Reunion}} The Rolex Monterey Motorsports Reunion, formerly known as the Monterey Historics until 2010, is held the final weekend of Monterey Car Week at [[Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca|WeatherTech Raceway Laguna Seca]]. The four-day event has over 500 participants, and generally features a specific marque every year. The Monterey Pre-Reunion is a two-day event held the previous Saturday and Sunday.
==Auctions== Automobile auctions of classic cars are held at various times and locations on the Monterey Peninsula. They are held by auction houses such as [[Bonhams]], [[RM Auctions]], [[Russo and Steele]], [[Gooding & Company]], Mecum Auctions, and Rick Cole Auctions. Total sales in 2014 were $463,744,226, with the high sale being a 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO berlinetta for $38,115,000.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Piff|first1=Tony|title=Defying All Predictions|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|pages=94-96}}</ref>
==Jet Center Party== The Jet Center Party, formally called the Motorworks Revival, is an invitation-only event held at the Monterey Jet Center the Wednesday before the Pebble Beach Concours. It is considered the unofficial kick-off for the week. It is hosted by [[Gordon McCall]]. Both exotic cars and private jets are displayed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bomstead|first1=Carl|title=Flying High Without Leaving the Ground|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|page=48}}</ref>
==Legends of the Autobahn== The Legends of the Autobahn show features German automobiles. It began as a [[BMW Car Club of America]] event and grew to include all German cars. It formerly showed Porsches also, but a separate event, the Porsche Werks Reunion, for Porsches was established in 2014. This event is free to the public.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carlson|first1=B. Mitchell|title=Legend Rolls On|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|page=50}}</ref> It is held at the Nicklaus Club - Monterey golf club.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Erik|title=German Metal! 2014 Legends of the Autobahn Concours|url=http://blog.caranddriver.com/german-metal-2014-legends-of-the-autobahn-concours-mega-gallery/|website=caranddriver.com|publisher=[[Car and Driver]]|accessdate=January 9, 2015|date=August 16, 2014}}</ref>
==Porsche Werks Reunion== The Porsche Werks Reunion event features Porsches and was established in 2014 after splitting off from the Legends of the Autobahn show. There were 519 cars on display at the initial event. This event was started by the [[Porsche Club of America]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kelly|first1=Prescott|title=Inaugural Werks Reunion: A Porsche Paradise|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|page=52}}</ref> It is held at the Rancho Canada Golf Club in Carmel Valley.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ely|first1=Trevor|title=Porsche Werks Reunion 2014 – Report and Photos|url=http://www.sportscardigest.com/porsche-werks-reunion-2014-report-photos/|publisher=Sports Car Digest|accessdate=January 9, 2014|date=August 22, 2014}}</ref>
==The Quail, A Motorsports Gathering== The Quail, A Motorsports Gathering (usually shortened to The Quail) is a car show limited to 200 automobiles located at the Quail Lodge & Golf Club. A maximum 3,000 tickets are sold to this event to avoid crowds. Unlike the Pebble Beach Concours, The Quail vehicles are not judged.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bomstead|first1=Carl|title=Plenty of Room, Plenty of Fun|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|page=54}}</ref><ref name=callaway>{{cite journal|last1=Callaway|first1=Sue|title=Luxury marketing’s secret sauce: Inside The Quail Motorsports event|journal=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=September 19, 2014|url=http://fortune.com/2014/09/19/quail-motorsports-marketing/|accessdate=January 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Concorso Italiano== The Concorso Italiano features Italian cars. It is held at the golf course at the Bayonet & Blackhorse Golf Club.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Piff|first1=Tony|title=Cutting Loose Italian-Style|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=November 2014|volume=26|issue=11|page=56}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
